column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=The organisms acting on protein matter aie of economic
#Text=imfwrtance from several distinct points of view.
#Text=That organic
#Text=nitrogenous compounds must be broken down in nature
#Text=into ammonia and nitrates that they may serve as nutrients
#Text=to vegetation, is evident.
#Text=These organisms likewise may interfere with the preservation of food, by changing its consistency,
#Text=its flavor or odor, or even by producing definite poisonous decomposition products termed ptomaines.
#Text=The changes in
#Text=consistency are of jiarticular importance with certain food products, such as cheese, and will be discussed under the general
#Text=
#Text=head of ripening processes.
#Text=The same may be said of the development of desirable flavors.
#Text=However, the development of
#Text=undesirable flavors and odors and of ptomaines calls for brief
#Text=disussion.
#Text=Putrefactive Substances having Disagreeable Odors and
#Text=Flavors. — A complete discussion of the compounds capable of
#Text=affecting the flavor or aroma that may be formed in nitrogenous
#Text=food would include a discussion of practically all decomposition
#Text=products formed.
#Text=A few distinctive products among those
#Text=most commonly found will be noted.
#Text=Butyric acid (C3H7COOH) and acetic acid (CH3COOH) are
#Text=not uncommonly formed in protein decomposition.
#Text=In the
#Text=putrefaction of such foods as meats, it is possible that these may
#Text=originate from the fats or carbohydrates present rather than
#Text=from the proteins.
#Text=Some putrefactive bacteria, however, do
#Text=form butyric acid from the native proteins.
#Text=Indol  and methyl indol or skatol are commonly formed from native proteins
#Text=or peptones in the absence of carbohydrates by many organisms.
#Text=These have an intensely disagreeable fecal odor.
#Text=Among the most disagreeable of the odors developed is that
#Text=from the mercaptans, particularly methyl mercaptan (CH3SH).
#Text=These and certain related compounds containing sulphur are
#Text=the common causes of the worst odors attendant upon putrefaction.
#Text=Hydrogen sulphide is also commonly formed, as in
#Text=rotten eggs.
